metadata.case_name: Appellant (successor of Shah Manilal Maganlal) v. Respondent firm

facts.text: There is a talukdari estate called the Bhankoda estate in Viramgam taluka in Ahmedabad district, jointly owned by several talukdars in different shares, comprising twelve villages including Rampura where suit lands are situate.
By Government Resolution No. 8170 dated 30th August 1912, the estate was taken under Government management under section 28 of the Gujarat Talukdars Act (Bombay Act VI of 1888).

Firm of Shah Manilal Maganlal and Bros., predecessors in interest of the appellant, desired to erect a ginning factory on survey Nos. 222, 223, 225 and 226 and approached Talukdari Settlement Officer for permanent lease.
Talukdari Settlement Officer agreed to grant lease subject to Government sanction.
By Resolution No. 10795 of 1917 dated 5th September 1917, Government of Bombay granted sanction. Exhibit 181 is certified copy of letter from Chief Secretary detailing steps.
On 9th December 1916, Shah Manilal Maganlal made written signed application to Talukdari Settlement Officer offering permanent lease of survey numbers at annual rental Rs. 290 for ginning factory.

On 12th July 1917, Talukdari Settlement Officer provisionally accepted offer after considering talukdars' objections, permitted entry on land in anticipation of sanction under section 27A Court of Wards Act (applicable via section 29G Gujarat Talukdars Act), submitted to Government.
Survey numbers in possession of tenants; lessee to settle privately or officer to eject.
On 20th July 1917, Commissioner forwarded papers to Government with recommendations.
Government sanctioned arrangement on 5th September 1917; binding agreement to lease effected.
Draft formal lease prepared but not executed or registered.
Lessee took possession soon after, erected ginning and pressing factory, bungalow, engine rooms; tendered and paid agreed rent to Talukdari Settlement Officer for about two years.
Estate released from Government management; manager appointed by talukdars continued receiving rent as settled.
On 4th May 1924, possessory mortgage of ginning factory and buildings by Shah Manilal Maganlal for Rs. 1,40,000 in favour of defendant.
Contestants acquired rights in 1924-25: defendant as mortgagee, plaintiffs as ijaradar and assignee of mortgage rights; plaintiffs received rent per grant.
In 1933, appellant purchased equity of redemption at court auction, vested with rights of Manilal Maganlal; property value ~Rs. 38,000.
Suit filed by respondent firm in July 1933 for ejectment of survey Nos. 222, 223, 225, 226 and mesne profits.

Plaint paras 2-3: admitted lease negotiated for 50 years at Rs. 290 but no formal registered lease, so trespassers; para 4: challenged officer's authority; para 8: received rent to 31st July 1932, no notice needed or given 25th Dec 1930.
Defendant pleaded: plaintiffs no right to sue (no landlord title), defendant permanent tenant, estoppel by conduct.
Trial Judge (Joint Sub-Judge, Ahmedabad, Suit No. 830/1933) decreed suit: no written lease, no equitable part performance.
Unsuccessful review on fresh materials.
Appeal to Assistant Judge, Ahmedabad (Appeal No. 173/1936): ground 3 on S.53A TPA; remand 30th July 1938 under O XLI R25 on issues: plaintiff mortgagee in occupation? Non-joinder?
Trial Judge post-remand: against plaintiffs, admitted Ex.181 etc.; Assistant Judge allowed appeal 27th April 1940: plaintiffs no title; S.53A applies.
High Court Bombay Second Appeal No. 717/1940: allowed appeal 9th March 1943, decreed for 223,225; dismissed for 222,226. Plaintiff title proved; Ex.181 not S.53A contract.
Plaintiff witness: read correspondence, unsure location; talukdars had records.

legal_issues.text: Whether the plaintiff firm has proved its title to maintain the suit in ejectment against the defendant.
Whether the defendant is entitled to the benefit of section 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: No formal registered lease, so trespassers; challenged authority of Talukdari Settlement Officer; received rent to 1932 but no notice needed.
Correspondence summarized in Ex.181 not evidence of contract; terms not ascertainable with certainty.

respondent_arguments.text: Plaintiffs have title as ijaradar/assignee; defendant paid rent treating as landlord.
S.53A: Ex.181 shows written signed contract, possession in part performance, willing to perform.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiff's title: not necessary to decide as S.53A protects defendant.

S.53A applies: Ex.181 reliable secondary evidence of written signed agreement (offer 9/12/1916, acceptance 12/7/1917, sanction 5/9/1917); terms ascertainable (permanent lease, Rs.290 rent, revise after 50 years); possession taken, structures built, rent paid continuously; willing/performed part.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred; secondary evidence admissible as originals withheld.

court_reasoning.text: No formal lease needed; agreement suffices. Possession post-sanction likely; rent admission in plaint.

holdings.text: Defendant entitled to protection under section 53-A of Transfer of Property Act as conditions satisfied.
High Court erred in reversing Assistant Judge; suit not maintainable against defendant under S.53A.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Talukdars Act (Bombay Act VI of 1888)
statutes_cited.relevance: Government management of estate; applicability of Court of Wards Act

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Part performance defence; debarred from ejectment

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Equity of part performance for leases (post 1/4/1930, not applicable here)

statutes_cited.name: Indian Registration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Unregistered lease agreement admissible as evidence of part performance

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and decree set aside; Assistant Judge's decree dismissing suit restored. Plaintiffs' suit for ejectment dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Defendant protected from ejectment under S.53A TPA

key_quotes.text: "Ex. 181 shows that the terms of the lease have been reduced to writing though no regular lease appears to have been executed. ... section 53-A of the Transfer of the Property Act is a complete answer."
key_quotes.speaker: Assistant Judge
key_quotes.significance: Basis for applying S.53A upheld by Supreme Court

key_quotes.text: "the correspondence Which is summarized in the Government Resolution cannot be regarded as evidence of the contract, and secondly, the terms of the contract also cannot be deduced from the correspondence with any reasonable certainty."
key_quotes.speaker: High Court

key_quotes.text: "We are therefore of the opinion that the learned Assistant Judge rightly dismissed the plaintiffs suit and the High Court was in error in interfering with that decision in second appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
